snippet: Imprisoning the wrong person almost always requires more than one overzealous detective, a mistaken witness or a suspect pushed into making false confessions.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column points out finding an individual to blame for a mistake does not always fix deeper problems; cites case of acclaimed retired detective Louis Scarcella, whose convictions are being examined by special team of prosecutors in Brooklyn after a man convicted largely on evidence developed by Scarcella was exonerated.
lead_paragraph: Imprisoning the wrong person almost always requires more than one overzealous detective, a mistaken witness or a suspect pushed into making false confessions.
